Install Dev Environment¶

To start a dev environment, make sure you have Poetry installed. Then run:

git clone https://github.com/benjaminye/portana.git
cd portana
poetry install

Run Demo¶

First cd into poetry’s virtual environment directory. You can find it via: poetry show -v

on Unix, run: source venv-name/Scripts/activate

on Windows, run (using Powershell): ./venv-name/Scripts/Activate.ps1

then, run ipython kernel install --name "portana" --user

Abstract class to return different data depending on each asset class

abstract get_security(isin: str, date_range: Tuple[str, str]) → portana.abstracts.data.AbstractSecurity¶

Retrieve security and data from database by isin and date_range

Parameters

  • isin (str) – Security’s ISIN (unique identifier)

  • date_range (Tuple[str, str]) – Date range by which to retrive data from. Should be in “yyyy-mm-dd” format.

Returns

Class containing information of the security

Return type

AbstractSecurity

class portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries¶

Abstract class for time series representation used in this package

Note

This class supports indexing by date. User can pass in date(s) in following ways:

TimeSeries[str] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on that date

TimeSeries[List[str]] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on dates in list

TimeSeries[begin:end:step] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on and between begin and end dates, with prescribed step size

abstract get_data() → Union[numpy.ndarray, Tuple[numpy.ndarray]]¶

Returns a numpy array(s) containing data

Returns

Numpy array of data contained in this object (excluding dates)

Return type

class portana.data.generator.Generator¶

Class used for generating random data. This is used by simulated module to generate random data.

seed¶

Seed for random number generator It is recommended for simulated module to use ISIN for seed so that return data stay the same

Type

int

max_drift¶

Maximum mean return used by random.normal to generate random return data for buiding price time series

Type

float

max_vol¶

Maximum standard deviation used by random.normal to generate random return data for building price time series

Type

float

max_distribution¶

Maximum added return to price time series to create total return index time series

Type

float

date_range¶

Date range to generate simulated data from Example: [“2001-01-01”, “2005-01-01”]

Type

Tuple[str, str]

initial_price_range¶

Range of desired initial price, used by random.uniform to set an initial price

Type

Tuple[int, int]

Example

>>> # Setting up a Generator
>>> generator = Generator()
>>> generator.set_max_drift(0.01)
>>> generator.set_max_vol(0.05)
>>> generator.set_max_distribution(0.005)
>>> generator.set_date_range(["2020-01-01", "2020-02-01"])
>>> generator.set_initial_price_range([5, 100])
>>> # Make sure to set seed last
>>> generator.set_seed(412843)

>>> # Using Generator
>>> generator.generate_dates()
numpy.ndarray
>>> generator.generate_prices()
numpy.ndarray
>>> generator.generate_sector()
"Technology"
generate_dates() → numpy.ndarray¶

Generate a numpy array of dates

Returns

Numpy array of dates set from set_date_range(date_range)

Return type

numpy.ndarray

generate_fee() → float¶

Generate a random fee

Currently setup to return a float between 0 and 0.02

Amount of fees

Return type

float

generate_geography() → str¶

Generate geography

Currently setup to randomly choose between United States and Canada

Returns

str

Currently set up to output “Simulated Security {seed}”

Returns

Security name

str

Returns

Return type

numpy.ndarray

Generate risk profile

Currently setup to randomly choose betwenn High, Medium, and Low

Returns

Return type

str

Currently set up to randomly choose between Technology, Industrials, and Financials

Returns

str

Currently setup to randomly choose between Growth, Income, Value, and Balanced

set_date_range(date_range: Tuple[str, str]) → None¶

Setter for date_range

Parameters

date_range (Tuple[str, str]) – Date range from which to generate time series data Example: (“2020-01-01”, “2020-02-01”)

set_initial_price_range(price_range: Tuple[int, int]) → None¶

Setter for initial_price_range

Parameters

price_range (Tuple[int, int]) – Initial price range of the security

set_max_distribution(max_distribution: float) → None¶

Setter for max_distribution

Parameters

max_distribution (float) – Maximum additional return tacked onto returns series generated by get_prices() to generate get_tot_ret_idx()

set_max_drift(max_drift: float) → None¶

Setter for max_drift

Parameters

max_drift (float) – Maximum average returns allowed

set_max_vol(max_vol: float) → None¶

Setter for max_vol

Parameters

max_vol (float) – Maximum standard deviation of returns allowed

set_seed(seed: int) → None¶

Setter method for seed

Sets seed, then runs a routine to set private attributes according to the seed set.

Parameters

seed (int) – The seed with which to feed into random number generator

Portana Timeseries¶

class portana.timeseries.analyzerseries.AnalyzerSeries(dates: numpy.ndarray, results: numpy.ndarray, col_names: List[str])¶

Class for time series representation for ouputs from Anlyzer classes. A concrete implementation of AbstractTimeSeries

Parameters

  • dates (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array containing dates, must be the same length (# of rows) as other parameters passed in

  • results (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array containing output of Analyzer results, must be the same length (# of rows) as other parameters passed in

  • col_names (List[str]) – Column names used by to_df() to construct a DataFrame

Note

This class supports indexing by date. User can pass in date(s) in following ways:

TimeSeries[str] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on that date

TimeSeries[List[str]] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on dates in list

TimeSeries[begin:end:step] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on and between begin and end dates, with prescribed step size

get_data() → numpy.ndarray¶

Returns a numpy array(s) containing data

Returns

Numpy array of data contained in this object (excluding dates)

Return type

numpy.ndarray

Returns

Numpy array of dates contained in this object

Return type

numpy.ndarray

Returns a pandas DataFrame object representing data contained in this object

Returns

DataFrame representation of this object

Return type

pandas.DataFrame

class portana.timeseries.simtimeseries.SimTimeSeries(dates: numpy.ndarray, prices: numpy.ndarray, tot_ret_idx: numpy.ndarray)¶

Class for representation of securities time series

Parameters

  • dates (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array containing dates, must be the same size as other parameters passed in

  • prices (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array containing prices, must be the same size as other parameters passed in

  • tot_ret_idx (np.ndarray) – Numpy array containing total return index, must be the same size as other parameters passed in

Note

This class supports indexing by date. User can pass in date(s) in following ways:

TimeSeries[str] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on that date

TimeSeries[List[str]] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on dates in list

TimeSeries[begin:end:step] -> AbstractTimeSeries:

Returns TimeSeries object containing data on and between begin and end dates, with prescribed step size

class portana.analyzer.equity_analyzer.EquityAnalyzer¶

Class to analyze equity-like securities

securities¶

List of securities to analyze

Type

List[AbstractSecurity]

comp_index¶

Benchmark to be compared against

Type

AbstractSecurity

add_security(security: portana.abstracts.data.AbstractSecurity) → None¶

Add a Security to analyze

Parameters

security (AbstractSecurity) – A Security to be analyzed

get_betas(mode: Union[Literal[px], Literal[tr]]) → Tuple[portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries, portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries]¶

Get betas of securities and benchmark

Note

Beta of benchmark against benchmark will always be 1

Parameters

mode (str) – “px” for price returns, “tr” for total returns

Returns

Tuple containing two AnalyzerSeries of betas for securities and comp_index

Return type

Tuple[AnalyzerSeries, AnalyzerSeries]

get_rebased_index(mode: Union[Literal[px], Literal[tr]], initial_val: float = 100.0) → Tuple[portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries, portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries]¶

Get a rebased indices of securities and benchmark

Parameters

  • mode (str) – “px” for index built on prices, “tr” for total returns index

  • initial_val (float) – Initial value of rebased index, defaults to 100

Returns

Tuple containing two AnalyzerSeries of rebased indices for securities and comp_index

Return type

Tuple[AnalyzerSeries, AnalyzerSeries]

get_returns(mode: Union[Literal[px], Literal[tr]]) → Tuple[portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries, portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries]¶

Get a returns of securities and benchmark

Parameters

mode (str) – “px” for price returns, “tr” for total returns

Returns

Tuple containing two AnalyzerSeries of returns for securities and comp_index

Return type

Tuple[AnalyzerSeries, AnalyzerSeries]

get_sharpes(mode: Union[Literal[px], Literal[tr]], adj_factor: int, rfr: float) → Tuple[portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries, portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries]¶

Get Sharpe ratios of securities and benchmark

Parameters

  • mode (str) – “px” for price returns, “tr” for total returns

  • adj_factor (int) – Adjustment factor to annualize volatility

  • rfr (float) – Risk free rate

Note

adj_factor should depend on the frequency of data:

  • Daily: 252 (number of trading days in a year)

  • Weekly: 52

  • Monthly: 12

  • Quarterly: 4

Returns

Tuple containing two AnalyzerSeries of Sharpe ratios for securities and comp_index

Return type

Tuple[AnalyzerSeries, AnalyzerSeries]

get_volatilities(mode: Union[Literal[px], Literal[tr]], adj_factor: int) → Tuple[portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries, portana.abstracts.timeseries.AbstractTimeSeries]¶

Get volatilities of securities and benchmark

Parameters

  • mode (str) – “px” for price returns, “tr” for total returns

  • adj_factor (int) –

    Adjustment factor to annualize volatility. Depending on data frequency…

    Daily: 252 (number of trading days) Weekly: 52 Monthly: 12 Quarterly: 4

Returns

Tuple containing two AnalyzerSeries of volatilities for securities and comp_index

Return type

Tuple[AnalyzerSeries, AnalyzerSeries]

set_comp_index(comp_index: portana.abstracts.data.AbstractSecurity) → None¶

Add a benchmark to compare against Also used for beta calculations

Note

Right now, this is optional as first time a security is added through add_security(security), comp_index will be set to that

Parameters

security (AbstractSecurity) – A Security containing benchmark to be compared against
